DataElement.preferredName: Recurrent Tumor Prior EGFRvIII Vaccine Positive EGFR Gene Amplification Indicator
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Indicator of whether or not the recurrent tumor is positive for EGFR gene amplicication in patients with prior EGFRvIII vaccine.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Recurrent Disease Neoplasm Prior EGFRvIII Vaccine Positive EGFR Gene Amplification
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: The return of a disease after a period of remission._A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias._Earlier in time or order._An antineoplastic vaccine directed against a peptide found in the epidermal growth factor receptor class III variant (EGFRvIII), a constitutively activated mutant of the wild-type tyrosine kinase. This protein variant is present in a substantial proportion of malignant gliomas and other human cancers._An observation confirming something, such as the presence of a disease, condition, or microorganism._This gene is involved in the epidermal growth factor signal transduction pathway._A cellular process characterized by the production of multiple copies of a particular gene or genes in the genome.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: The return of a disease after a period of remission.:A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias.

Concepts.definition: The return of a disease after a period of remission.

A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias.

Property.preferredName: Prior EGFRvIII Peptide Vaccine Positive Finding EGFR Gene Gene Amplification
Property.preferredDefinition: Earlier in time or order.:An antineoplastic vaccine directed against a peptide found in the epidermal growth factor receptor class III variant (EGFRvIII), a constitutively activated mutant of the wild-type tyrosine kinase. This protein variant is present in a substantial proportion of malignant gliomas and other human cancers.:An observation confirming something, such as the presence of a disease, condition, or microorganism.:This gene is involved in the epidermal growth factor signal transduction pathway.:A cellular process characterized by the production of multiple copies of a particular gene or genes in the genome.

Concepts.definition: An antineoplastic vaccine directed against a peptide found in the epidermal growth factor receptor class III variant (EGFRvIII), a constitutively activated mutant of the wild-type tyrosine kinase. This protein variant is present in a substantial proportion of malignant gliomas and other human cancers.
A finding of abnormality following an examination or observation confirming something, such as the presence of a disease, condition, or microorganism.
This gene is involved in the epidermal growth factor signal transduction pathway.
Any DNA sequence rearrangement that results in the gain of one or more copies of a DNA segment that contains at least one gene.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the results of evaluations of the patient and the patient's disease.

Concepts.definition: A response or indicator that can have a value of yes, no, or not applicable.
